Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ARTS: Integrative Research and Training in Tropical Taxonomy
Award.AbstractNarration:
Taxonomy, the science of finding, describing and naming organisms, is vital to biological research and conservation of life's diversity. The on-going effort to survey, inventory, and preserve the ocean's biological diversity is threatened by a shortage of taxonomic expertise. Although focused on Caribbean biodiversity, the overarching goal of this project is to promote conservation of marine biodiversity around the world. This project will make it easier to correctly identify and document marine biodiversity, to detect invasive species, and to protect rare and endangered species by training new taxonomists, by developing Internet-based resources to support taxonomic research, and by making taxonomic methods easily accessible to non-specialists. This project will create new taxonomic descriptions and revisions of currently undescribed species from the Caribbean, which will be immediately useful to any researcher, manager, or conservation practitioner working in the region, and will contribute to the species inventory of the Caribbean. Open-access videos and how-to guides will allow specialists to convey enthusiasm for these organisms to the public, to managers, and to policy makers, and provide a way for students and the general public to learn more about taxonomy.

This project has three parts with complementary aims. Part A will document the biodiversity of 6 groups of marine organisms with high, but poorly known, diversity in the Southern Caribbean (sponges, hydroids, sea anemones, sea squirts, ribbon worms, and seaweeds). This work will emphasize the integration of traditional morphological and molecular characters with non-traditional characters such as larval morphology, live coloration, and characters derived from confocal and electron microscopy. Established experts will work closely with experts-in-training, with a focus on species from the Caribbean coast of Panama that are known to be in particular need of taxonomic revision. Part B will provide training workshops for graduate students and junior researchers interested in developing taxonomic expertise in one of 6 focal groups; enabling them to (1) identify species in the field, (2) efficiently collect and preserve material for subsequent taxonomic work, (3) use existing keys or monographs to identify material to species, and (4) develop personal connections with a global network of other students and specialists. Part C will make the basic skills and vocabulary involved in the taxonomy of all 6 groups globally accessible to both expert and non-specialist workers in biodiversity and conservation. This part will develop a standard package of internet-based tools for each group, including a set of how-to videos and illustrated definitions of technical terms, with translations into several languages. This toolkit will be designed to facilitate rapid biodiversity documentation and to increase the precision of preliminary field identifications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Despite that the marine environment makes up most of our planet and humanity is highly dependent on it, it is poorly known and we are far away from understanding its biological diversity. In these times of high concern about the loss of the natural world around us and of increasing efforts to know and preserve the biodiversity of the planet, we face the challenge of the so-called taxonomic shortage. Taxonomy— the science of describing, naming and classifying organisms— is in decline, with few experts able to study and document the organisms around us. This gap of expertise and knowledge is more pronounced in the oceans, limiting our ability to identify, understand and conserve the biodiversity of our planet.

The goal of this project is to combine taxonomic research, training and the development of tools to facilitate and overcome the taxonomic impediment in six groups of tropical marine invertebrates: sponges, hydroids, sea anemones, sea squirts, ribbon worms, and sea weeds. We are a group of international experts working to enhance expertise and develop the next generation of taxonomists at the same time that we document the diversity of these marine groups in Panama. We have produced a standard package of online tools for each study group including a set of "how-to" videos and protocols, and an online illustrated glossary in multiple languages of technical terms sourced by experts. These tools have been designed in a web framework to facilitate rapid taxonomic documentation and to make the taxonomy and identification of these organisms more accessible to both expert and non-specialist workers in biodiversity and conservation.   

This part of the project is focused on sea anemones, a group of marine invertebrates related to corals and jellyfish. Despite their relative simplicity, sea anemones are a diverse group of animals present in every marine habitat, from the shallow waters to the deepest parts of the oceans. However, sea anemones are poorly known, especially in tropical environments in which corals tend to dominate. In the course of this work, we made new collections of sea anemones that helped us clarify the identity of several species, and revised existing records of sea anemones from Panama. We have documented 16 species from 15 shallow water locations in the Panamanian Caribbean (Bocas del Toro Province), and five locations in the Panamanian Pacific (Los Santos Province, and the Pearl Islands in Panama Province). The updated list of sea anemones from Panama now includes 30 valid species, including a previously unknown species of sea anemone and seven new records for the country.

 

This project has supported nearly a dozen undergraduate and graduate trainees through a hands-on field course in Panama, in which the students learned to collect, preserve, document and identify sea anemones. In addition, the project provided extended personalized training in the taxonomy of sea anemones to one female graduate student. The outcomes of the project have been shared with the general public at several public events including outreach talks, and via guest lectures to audiences from kindergarten to college level.
